facts.text: Plaintiffs and defendants governed by aliyasantana law of inheritance, a matriarchal system.
Pammadi was prepositor of the family; had two daughters Pammakke and Dejappe, three sons Kanthu Hegde, Monu Hegde, Manjappa Hegde.
After Pammadi's death, differences arose; all major members except Brahamiah referred disputes to arbitration via mutchallika dated December 14, 1886.
By 1886, Kanthu Hegde and Monu Hegde had died; kutumba had two santhathi kavaru (Pammakke, Dejappe) and one nissanthathi kavaru (Manjappa Hegde).
Arbitrators divided kutumba properties into two parts: one to Pammakke's kavaru, other to Dejappe's kavaru and Manjappa Hegde.
Award decree Ex. A-2 rendered on strength of mutchallika; properties separated for enjoyment, but Adu Hegde continued as Yejman; joint rituals to continue; accounts to be shown till debts discharged.
On June 14, 1953, members of Pammakke's kavaru filed suit for partition under s.35 of Madras Aliyasantana Act, 1949.
Appellants (defendants 34,35 from Dejappe's kavaru) resisted claiming kutumba partitioned under Ex. A-2 or deemed under s.36(6).
Trial court held Ex. A-2 effected partition or covered by s.36(6).
Mysore High Court in Regular Appeal No.37/1958 reversed on July 7, 1965: Ex. A-2 not partition; not covered by s.36(6) as award decree not 'award'.
Brahmiah did not join mutchallika A-1; not party to Ex. A-2.

legal_issues.text: Whether under the award decree Exh. A-2, the kutumba/family of the plaintiffs and the defendants stood partitioned.
If the answer to the first question is in the negative, whether the said award decree comes within the scope of s.36(6) of the Madras Aliyasantana Act, 1949.

petitioner_arguments.text: Ex. A-2 evidences a partition of the kutumba properties.
Ex. A-2 is alternatively a deemed partition under s.36(6); 'award' includes award decree; Brahmiah acquiesced.

respondent_arguments.text: Ex. A-2 does not evidence partition; not covered by s.36(6) as it is an award decree, not a mere award.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.36(6) Madras Aliyasantana Act, 1949; Parameshwari Hengsu case

court_reasoning.text: Under aliyasantana law, partition impermissible without consent of all adults; three types of arrangements: temporary maintenance, permanent maintenance (jointness intact), full partition.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Permanent arrangements for separate enjoyment without disrupting jointness common.

court_reasoning.text: Ex. A-2 provides for separate living/enjoyment but retains Yejman (Adu Hegde), joint rituals, accounts to Yejman, no disruption of oneness; clauses inconsistent with out-and-out partition.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Kutumba not disrupted; agrees with High Court.

court_reasoning.text: Tests for s.36(6) from Gummanna Shetty: registered settlement/award; all major members parties; whole properties distributed; among kavarus for absolute enjoyment in perpetuity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Award' includes award decree; overrules Parameshwari Hengsu on this point.

court_reasoning.text: Brahmiah not party to mutchallika A-1 or Ex. A-2; acquiescence does not make him party; strict compliance required for deemed partition.

holdings.text: Ex. A-2 does not evidence a partition.
Award decree is 'award' under s.36(6), but Ex. A-2 not covered as not all major members were parties.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gummanna Shetty and ors. v. Nagaveniamma
precedents_cited.relevance: Lays down tests for s.36(6); arrangement for separate enjoyment without disruption not partition.
Characteristics of maintenance arrangements vs. partition.

precedents_cited.case_name: Appa and ors. v. Kachai Bay van Kuti and ors.
Mudara and ors. v. Muthu Hengsu
Parameshwari Hengsu and ors. v. Venkappa Shetty and ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Incorrectly held award decree not 'award' under s.36(6).

statutes_cited.name: Madras Aliyasantana Act, 1949 (Madras Act IX of 1949)
statutes_cited.relevance: s.35 allows claim for partition; s.36(6) deems certain registered settlements/awards as partitions.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; Ex. A-2 neither actual partition nor deemed under s.36(6); parties to bear own costs in Supreme Court.
outcome.costs: Parties to bear their own costs in this Court.

key_quotes.text: "the members of the kutumba should live in different houses, by bestowing labour and without quarreling with each other as proper arrangements were made for the maintenance of the kutumba without disrupting its oneness."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Shows Ex. A-2 retained jointness, not partition.

key_quotes.text: "A person by merely submitting to an arrangement made may be bound by the arrangement but thereby he does not become a party to the arrangement."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Whether we consider the principle underlying s.36(6) or the language of s.36(6), we see no justification to exclude award decrees from the scope of s.36(6)."
key_quotes.speaker: court
